agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $250,000 the first year and $300,000 the second year from the
general fund to support the establishment of the Fetal
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $250,000 the first year and $300,000 the second year from the
general fund to support the establishment of the Fetal Infant Mortality Review Team pursuant to
House Bill 997, which establishes the Fetal and Infant Mortality Review Team to develop and
implement procedures to ensure that fetal and infant deaths occurring in the Commonwealth are
analyzed in a systematic way. The bill requires the Team to compile triennial statistical data
regarding fetal and infant deaths and to make such data available to the Governor, the General
Assembly, and the Department of Health. The bill provides that information and records
obtained or created by the Team and portions of meetings of the Team at which individual fetal
and infant deaths are discussed shall be confidential.

agencyName: Natural and Historic Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $884,800 the first year from the general fund to Bedford County for
emergency stabilization the 1857 Slave Dwelling
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $884,800 the first year from the general fund to Bedford County for
emergency stabilization the 1857 Slave Dwelling at Thomas Jefferson's Poplar Forest. Poplar
Forest has completed a series of emergency stabilization measures to protect the structure,
Patron Order 16
Request to Amend House Bill 30, as Introduced
including buttressing the building with support beams in 1993 following a derecho, and a series
of repairs to secure the walls. A full restoration of the 1857 Slave Dwelling offers a unique
opportunity to reveal the untold stories of the enslaved African Americans who lived and
worked at Poplar Forest during the decades before and immediately following Emancipation
and to provide a physical space where visitors, and descendants can connect to their history. A
more equitable interpretation of all who lived here is central to our mission and our
responsibility to share the full story of Poplar Forest.
primaryRecipientName: Bedford County for emergency stabilization the 1857 Slave Dwelling at Thomas Jefferson's Poplar Forest
recipientRawText: to Bedford County for emergency stabilization the 1857 Slave Dwelling at Thomas Jefferson's Poplar Forest

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000,000 in fiscal year 2025 and $50,000,000 in fiscal year 2026
to establish the 5000 Families pilot program, which will provide monthly rental assistance to
low-income families with school-aged children. Eligible households will receive a monthly
rental voucher in an amount sufficient to allow the family to pay only 30 percent of their
monthly income for housing. This program will empower families and their children by
ensuring they have a stable home and thus a strong foundation for success at school and
beyond.

agencyName: Natural and Historic Resources FY24-25 FY25-26

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $500,000 the first year from the general fund to support restoration
of Douglass Cemetery in Alexandria. This reques
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $500,000 the first year from the general fund to support restoration
of Douglass Cemetery in Alexandria. This request is a match to City CIP funds and will allow
for the historic African American cemetery to be restored to its original 1895 vision. Douglass
Cemetery is an abandoned historic African American cultural resource in the City of Alexandria
that is experiencing severe flooding, with drainage issues causing the ground level to sink and
headstones to topple over. The Office of Historic Alexandria is seeking an additional $500,000
from the State to complete the preservation work necessary to stabilize the landscape of the
cemetery and resolve the extensive drainage issues. These final stabilization efforts include sod
and landscape repairs, headstone conservation, and necessary archaeological testing.
primaryRecipientName: City CIP funds and will allow for the historic African American cemetery to be restored to its original 1895 vision

descriptionFull:

divisions that serve communities with high incidences of community violence to contract for
community-based mental health services for students from public or private community-based
providers or to fund the hiring of additional specialized support staff to meet student needs. This
funding is necessary due to the expiration of federal stimulus funding that allowed school
divisions to cover these costs in the recent years following the pandemic.

descriptionFull:

include cardiac sonographer training, critical care and heart failure management training,

descriptionShort:
This amendment requests approximately $198.3 million over the biennium to produce nearly
20,000 additional Virginians for the workforce tale
descriptionFull:
This amendment requests approximately $198.3 million over the biennium to produce nearly
20,000 additional Virginians for the workforce talent pipeline in high-demand sectors aligned
with the nine GO Virginia regions. The investment will build on existing programs to expand
capacity at a regional level, to produce 20,000 more credentialed workers than the community
colleges currently produce and will address the unmet industry need for talent in healthcare,
advanced manufacturing, skilled trades, transportation, energy, and information technology. It is
expected that industries have already provided a $21.7 million investment and will invest an
additional $24.6 million in the future and the community college system will redirect $11
million of existing college resources.

local public libraries. This funding represents the third installment of a four-year plan to fully
fund the state library aid formula by fiscal year 2026. This plan is currently established as the
objective of the General Assembly in Subsection D of Item 227 that was enacted in 2022.

descriptionFull:

services rates to $33.89 per hour in Northern Virginia and $31.21 per hour in the rest of the
state, based on assumptions used in the Burns & Associates Rates Model developed for the
Deportment of Behavioral Health and Developmental Services in 2021. It will provide funds for
competitive wages, address wage compression created by minimum wage increases and address
rising costs for personal care providers employed by agencies.

Patron Order 96

provided by primary care physicians, pediatricians and psychiatrists by five percent care or 80
percent of the Medicare rate for equivalent services, whichever is higher. Language also
requires the agency to establish an annual inflation adjustment for Medicaid services provided
by a physician which shall be used to update the rates in the following year. Language provides
the agency with the authority to implement emergency regulations to effect such changes.

descriptionFull:

hours needed for certification.

descriptionFull:

agencyName: Request to Amend House Bill 30, as Introduced
descriptionShort:
This amendment adds $425,750 each year from the general fund for the Department of Social
Services to expand their existing program to find
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $425,750 each year from the general fund for the Department of Social
Services to expand their existing program to find relative and fictive kin. The current program
eligibility is for youth 12-17 years of age who are placed in congregate care or who have been
in foster care for twelve months or more and are not placed with kinship foster parents.
Additional funding will allow any child who is placed in foster care to be assigned a team of
five individuals who will work quickly to identify a kinship placement.

descriptionShort:

the general fund and $4.3 million the first year
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $4.4 million the first year and $12.5 million the second year from
the general fund and $4.3 million the first year and $12.3 million the second year from
nongeneral funds to replace the benefits eligibility system currently used by approximately 2.2
million Virginians to apply for Medicaid, the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program,
Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, the Child Care Subsidy Program, and two Energy
Assistance Programs. The current legacy systems would be replaced by a next-generation, low-
code application platform supporting best practices in information technology architecture,
human-centered design, testing, and training.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $250,000 each year from the general fund for radio reading services.
There are five radio reading services in the Co
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $250,000 each year from the general fund for radio reading services.
There are five radio reading services in the Commonwealth that connect Virginians who are
blind and vision impaired to information, news, community and culture using technology and
the human voice. Last year these programs grew by eight percent and need additional support to
service those additional listeners and prepare for and reach more listeners as the population
ages.

agencyName: Natural and Historic Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:

descriptionFull:

Virginia Beautiful in order to support its environmental education program for teens as well as

agencyName: Natural and Historic Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $1.0 million from the general fund the first year and $500,000 from
the general fund the second year to Henrico Coun
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $1.0 million from the general fund the first year and $500,000 from
the general fund the second year to Henrico County to support expansion efforts at Lewis Ginter
Botanical Garden. This appropriation will help with a $31 million expansion Lewis Ginter has
undertaken with privately raised funding of $20.1 million. The first expansion in the Garden in
19 years, this project will increase their ability to provide top-tier quality programs, resources,
and experiences for statewide school districts, teachers and instructors, and community
members. Their programs and resources span topics such as environmental literacy, scientific
curriculum supplementation and support, nutrition education, health and wellness, and
sustainable practices. Visitation in 2023 exceeded 500,000 people from Virginia and throughout
the United States.
primaryRecipientName: Henrico County
recipientRawText: to Henrico County to support expansion efforts at Lewis Ginter Botanical Garden

facilities and other institutions, and services to prevent institutionalization. Funding is needed to
meet increasing requests for these services and increased cost of doing business including rent,
fuel and transportation. This increase would provide $100,000 annually to each of the 17
Centers for Independent Living.

descriptionFull:

considered by the 2024 Session of the General Assembly which would direct the Department of
Juvenile Justice to convene a workgroup to further study the research and evidence relied upon
by the Department when amendment its length of stay guidelines in 2023. The established work
group would study and review staffing ratios; the ability for Bon Air Juvenile Correctional
Center to staff the community treatment model and all therapeutic, education, and vocational
programs; the rates of serious incidents at Bon Air since January 2022. The workgroup will
include key stakeholders including youth advocates, representatives from the Indigent Defense
Commission, and the Disability Law Center. This amendment is a placeholder until a fiscal
impact statement for the legislation is provided.

beyond.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $175,000 the first year from the general fund to continue the
Exceptional Circumstances Payment pilot program which
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $175,000 the first year from the general fund to continue the
Exceptional Circumstances Payment pilot program which provides funding in emergency
situations for up to $3,000 per month for up to three months to ensure a safe and stable
placement for children in foster care. DSS is currently using Safe and Sound funding to pay for
this pilot until the start of fiscal year 2025. The agency will eventually be able to access Title
IV-E funding as an element of "maintenance payments" made to support the supervision of
children in foster care, but this requires federal approval through the modification of the Title
IV-E plan. This proposed amendment will continue the program until fiscal year 2026 to allow
DSS to get federal approval of the modification of their Title IV-E plan.

descriptionFull:

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment adds $1.4 million from the general fund and $7.7 million from nongeneral
funds each year to increase reimbursement rates for
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $1.4 million from the general fund and $7.7 million from nongeneral
funds each year to increase reimbursement rates for remote patient monitoring of patients
receiving take home medication for medication assisted treatment for opioid use disorders.
While take home medication for MAT is currently permitted, the lack of remote patient
monitoring to ensure the daily dosage of medication is taken has limited the ability of providers
to utilize take home medications. Remote patient monitoring for this purpose ensures the patient
takes the medication, which is critical to ensuring treatment protocols are followed and reduces
the risk of diversion. In addition, it reduces the travel time for patients who receive daily MAT
treatments, which increases adherence to the treatment protocol and their ability to maintain
employment.

descriptionShort:
This amendment adds language requiring the Department of Medical Assistance Services to
treat Medicaid recipients of community based care si
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds language requiring the Department of Medical Assistance Services to
treat Medicaid recipients of community based care similarly to those in nursing homes when
determining how medical care costs incurred by the recipient are applied to Medicaid eligibility,
required patient payments and the period for which the cost of care is incurred. Medicaid
spenddown refers to a requirement for individuals or families who otherwise meet all the
Medicaid non-financial and resource eligibility requirements, but whose countable income
exceeds the medically needy income limit for their city or county of residence. A spenddown is
similar to an insurance policy deductible.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment adds $250,000 from the general fund and $250,000 from nongeneral funds the
first year and language directing the agency to en
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds $250,000 from the general fund and $250,000 from nongeneral funds the
first year and language directing the agency to ensure that information on Medicaid managed
care organization preferred provider programs are provided to all CSBs. Funding would be used
to procure a contractor to assist in this effort. "Obtaining "preferred provider" status with
managed care organizations could reduce the administrative complexity of billing for Medicaid-
eligible services, helping CSBs increase reimbursement for Medicaid-eligible services.
Designation as a "preferred provider" means that the provider is not required to meet prior
authorization requirements for certain services. Reducing prior authorization requirements can
allow consumers to receive services more quickly and require fewer administrative steps before
CSBs are able to receive reimbursement for services delivered.

descriptionFull:

support for seniors and connections to affordable services.

descriptionShort:
This amendment adds language requiring the Department of Medical Assistance Services to
treat Medicaid recipients of community based care si
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds language requiring the Department of Medical Assistance Services to
treat Medicaid recipients of community based care similarly to those in nursing homes when
determining how medical care costs incurred by the recipient are applied to Medicaid eligibility,
required patient payments and the period for which the cost of care is incurred. Medicaid
spenddown refers to a requirement for individuals or families who otherwise meet all the
Medicaid non-financial and resource eligibility requirements, but whose countable income
exceeds the medically needy income limit for their city or county of residence. A spenddown is
similar to an insurance policy deductible.

Program Fund established pursuant to Chapter 493, 2021 Special Session I. The Rebate
Program is established to provide rebates to qualifying Commonwealth residents who purchase
a new or used electric vehicle with a base price of up to $55,000. The rebate would total $2,500
for qualified residents with household incomes greater than 300 percent of the Federal poverty
guidelines, and the rebate would total $4,500 for qualified residents with household incomes
equal to or less than 300 percent of the Federal poverty guidelines.

agencyName: Natural and Historic Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $1.3 million the first year from the general fund to Clarke County
for capital improvements at Historic Clermont Far
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $1.3 million the first year from the general fund to Clarke County
for capital improvements at Historic Clermont Farm. The appropriation would support building
a working replacement barn for the 360 acre cattle and sheep farm at the Historic Clermont
Farm in Clarke County. The Clermont Farm, comprised of structures dating to the mid-18th
Patron Order 396
Request to Amend House Bill 30, as Introduced
century, has been a state owned property since 2004 and is on the Virginia Landmarks Register
and National Register of Historic Places. The barn was used for agricultural educational
programs for public school students and working farmers, as a Virginia extension venue. The
farm sustained a major loss due to a 2018 fire, and has received $1.6 million from the associated
insurance settlement. The total estimated cost of the project is $2.9 million.
primaryRecipientName: the 360 acre cattle and sheep farm at the Historic Clermont Farm in Clarke County

descriptionShort:
This amendment adds language directing the agency to implement a change in scope process
July 1, 2024 by which FQHCs may request a reimburse
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds language directing the agency to implement a change in scope process
July 1, 2024 by which FQHCs may request a reimbursement change to reflect the scope for
services that have been added or changed. It further provides that FQHCs can request this scope
of services change dating back to October 1, 2018 as long as the request is made no later than
October 1, 2024. Thereafter, a request for a change in scope must be made within 15 months of
the change taking place. Finally, this amendment authorizes DMAS to reimburse an FQHC for
unreimbursed costs for up to two years prior to the FQHC’s initial request for a change in scope.
This will allow the FQHCs to cover their costs of patient care during this period through receipt
of the full federal match for these reimbursements.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $33.0 million the first year and $2.6 million the second year from
the general fund to ensure existing crisis centers are fully staffed. This amendment redirects
proposed funding to establish new crisis centers in order to ensure all crisis centers are fully
staffed before establishing new ones. Existing crisis stabilization units have bed capacity that is
not fully utilized because of lack of staff and additional funding could help existing centers hire
the staff they need to operate all or more of their licensed beds.

management, psychiatric rehabilitation services, and care coordination services.

This amendment expands the definition of "appropriate community housing" to enable the
Department of Behavioral Health and Developmental Ser
descriptionFull:

Developmental Services Trust Fund appropriations for community-based housing all DBHDS
populations, not just individuals with intellectual disabilities leaving training centers. The
current language was drafted on the outset of the Olmstead Settlement Agreement, but training
centers have almost all closed and the state psychiatric hospital census crisis has worsened.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $40,000,000 over the biennium to capitalize the Electric Vehicle
Rebate Program Fund established pursuant to Chapter 493, 2021 Special Session I. The Rebate
Program is established to provide rebates to qualifying Commonwealth residents who purchase
a new or used electric vehicle with a base price of up to $55,000. The rebate would total $2,500
for qualified residents with household incomes greater than 300 percent of the Federal poverty
guidelines, and the rebate would total $4,500 for qualified residents with household incomes
equal to or less than 300 percent of the Federal poverty guidelines.

Patron Order 519

however, there is no coverage for corrective lenses to address and/or treat conditions identified

excluded from this coverage change.

extension would allow more individuals to qualify for the monthly maintenance payment of
$811. This amendment corresponds with House Bill 1313 of the 2024 General Assembly.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $101,510 each year from the general fund to fund the administrative

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $101,510 each year from the general fund to fund the administrative
costs of allowing any adoptee 18 years of age or older access to their original birth certificate.
Currently, the Department of Social Services only processes requests for birth certificates when
the birth parents cannot be identified from the adoption file to assist in conducting a search, and
only if good cause was shown by the adoptee. The Department currently receives around 350
birth certificate requests annually and this amendment is estimated the double the workload.
The Department would also require 1.0 FTE to sustain the increase in requests and provide
related technical assistance and training. This amendment corresponds with House Bill 550
from the 2024 General Assembly.

Patron Order 571

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $250,000 each year from the general fund to support Hero's Bridge
Patron Order 571
Request to Amend House Bill 30, as Introduced
supportive services to aging veterans across the Commonwealth. It will also support the
building of a 44 unit pocket community of micro-housing for veteran senior citizens in
Warrenton, Virginia. The community will house low income, at-risk senior veterans. The
community will provide permanent supportive housing with a community center that will
provide a medical clinic, food pantry, counseling, transportation and other senior supports. Two
units will also be dedicated to emergency housing for elderly homeless veterans in need of rapid
housing. This funding will be particularly helpful to offset pre-development expenses of
permitting and initial site work. We are confident this prototype Village will be an example for
other communities on how to increase and diversify the housing stock for seniors.

descriptionFull:

general fund to establish the Health Innovation Fund. From this fund $1.5 million each year is
for competitive grants from the Health Innovation Fund, prioritizing high need areas that are
ready to begin a training program. Another $250,000 matching competitive grants the first year
is for seed money to initially fund five organizations to support regional employer-led collective
models the first year and four organizations to support regional employer-led collective models
the second year based on GoVirginia nine regions with funding awards being matched by
regional employers. Additionally, $500,000 the first year and $500,000 the second year is for
George Mason University Data Center to assist the Virginia Health Workforce Development
Authority with data collection and evaluation of the Health Innovation Fund. The Virginia
Health Workforce Development Authority will provide central oversight and regulatory review
of the Health Innovation Fund.

ensure quality accessible services for people li
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $775,000 each year from the general fund for workforce retention to
ensure quality accessible services for people living with brain injury. State contracted brain
injury providers report high attrition and difficulty filling open positions because of non-
competitive salaries and benefits. Delivery of programs and services suffer and client needs can
go unmet. This funding will support currently existing state contracted brain injury service
providers.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $2.5 million each year from the general fund to strengthen and
expand the existing state contracted safety net brain
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $2.5 million each year from the general fund to strengthen and
expand the existing state contracted safety net brain injury services system by increasing the
numbers of case managers, clubhouse staff, clinical professional staff and/or program support
staff. Programs have waiting lists for services and programs struggle to meet existing demands
from this challenging population that requires specialized support. Ten percent of the allocation
will go to support development of new safety net services in unserved areas of the state.

legislation introduced in the 2023 General Assembly Session. This amendment is a placeholder
until a fiscal impact statement for the bill is produced.

agencyName: Request to Amend House Bill 30, as Introduced
descriptionShort:

descriptionFull:

the standard is for one deputy for the greater of 1,500 in population, or every 25 square miles of
that locality. Preliminary estimates project an additional 265 state-funded sheriff deputies
resulting from the proposed legislation. A companion amendment adjusts the staffing table for
these additional positions. This amendment is a placeholder until a fiscal impact statement for
the bill is produced.

descriptionFull:

positions.

Reduction amounts assumed herein account for a mid-year first year implementation for the

Patron Order 590

prevention and college access services to over 2,000 students. Project Discovery's last state
budget increase was in the 2018-2020 biennium. The new funding would support Project
Discovery's 145 schools in 48 different school districts by expanding programming, increasing
enrollment, and supplementing compensation packages.

This amendment provides VSU with $50.0 million the first year from the general fund.
Virginia's HBCUs jointly seek to address the lack of fi
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides VSU with $50.0 million the first year from the general fund.
Virginia's HBCUs jointly seek to address the lack of financial resources. HBCUs in Virginia
have been underfunded, directly impacting their ability to contribute to the State's economy
through instruction, research and public service. Also, funding will assist with creating a strong
workforce and directly impact students, faculty, staff, alumni and community. The
underinvestment in these institutions contribute to a lack of educational and economic
opportunities.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $295,000 each year from the general fund to increase access to
pediatric treatment for Sickle Cell Disease. In FY 20
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $295,000 each year from the general fund to increase access to
pediatric treatment for Sickle Cell Disease. In FY 2007, state funding for the program was at
$450,000. However, state budget cuts continued to reduce the program funding until it reached
it's current funding of $305,000. The number of sickle cell patients/clients has increased and the
program has not been able to provide all of the services to all of the clients that they were able
to provide in the past. This funding reflects the growth in the costs of services and will allow
more clients to be served.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $145,000 from the general fund each year to increase access to
treatment for adults with Sickle Cell Disease. Current program funding is $805,000 a year. The
Tidewater area has a very large concentration of sickle cell clients, however, no program was

Commonwealth. Funding will match federal funding received from the United States
Department of Health Resources and Services Administration for the management of the
Virginia Area Health Education Centers. $250,000 each year will go toward oversight and
management of the graduate medical education programs for primary care and $250,000 each
year will provide central oversight and regulatory review of the Health Innovation Fund.
Current funding for the Authority is $300,000 each year from the general fund.

descriptionFull:

general fund to establish the Health Innovation Fund pursuant to Senate Bill 155. From this
fund $1.5 million each year is for competitive grants from the Health Innovation Fund,
prioritizing high need areas that are ready to begin a training program. Another $250,000
matching competitive grants the first year is for seed money to initially fund five organizations
to support regional employer-led collective models the first year and four organizations to
support regional employer-led collective models the second year based on GoVirginia nine
regions with funding awards being matched by regional employers. Additionally, $500,000 the
first year and $500,000 the second year is for George Mason University Data Center to assist
the Virginia Health Workforce Development Authority with data collection and evaluation of
the Health Innovation Fund. The Virginia Health Workforce Development Authority will
provide central oversight and regulatory review of the Health Innovation Fund.

descriptionShort:

amendment provides that the rate ceiling, currently t
descriptionFull:
This amendment clarifies that inflation is provided to PRTF providers every year. This
amendment provides that the rate ceiling, currently the statewide weighted average, does not
apply to PRTF providers accepting children that require EPSDT services. Federal regulations
require coverage of EPSDT services. These changes are not effective until the next rebasing
takes effect in 2026 but will allow providers and the agency to plan for the next rebasing and
ensure that the cost report process, which will begin in 2025, accounts for these changes.

of community violence who is determined by a health care provider to be at risk of repeat injury
or retaliation.

descriptionFull:

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $5.0 million the second year from the general fund to reflect an
estimate of the Commonwealth's contributions as an
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $5.0 million the second year from the general fund to reflect an
estimate of the Commonwealth's contributions as an employer under Senate Bill 373, which
requires the Virginia Employment Commission to establish and administer a paid family and
medical leave insurance program with benefits beginning January 1, 2027. Under the program,
benefits are paid to covered individuals, as defined in the bill, for family and medical leave.
Funding for the program is provided through premiums assessed to employers and employees
beginning January 1, 2026. The bill provides that the amount of a benefit is 80 percent of the
employee's average weekly wage, not to exceed 80 percent of the state weekly wage, which
amount is required to be adjusted annually to reflect changes in the statewide average weekly
wage. The bill caps the duration of paid leave at 12 weeks in any application year and provides
self-employed individuals the option of participating in the program.

descriptionFull:

weighted average methodology for positions per pupil and funded salaries within Basic Aid.
This cost estimate is based on a current ratio of 27.89 positions per 1,000 ADM. This is an
estimate. The actual fiscal impact is to be determined.

descriptionFull:

It would also oversee the employment of predictive analytics to improve early identification and
intervention efforts for academically at-risk cadets.

descriptionFull:

student orientations and cultural programming, and prepare a variety of presentations related to
immigration and international student concerns.

up to $20,000 of firefighter pension benefits in taxable year 2024, up to $30,000 in taxable year

general fund revenue reduction of $100.0 million each year as a placeholder since this
subtraction would result in a significant negative impact to the general fund. The actual revenue
impact is to be determined.

descriptionShort:
This amendment directs the Department of Education to work collaboratively with the
Department of Behavioral Health and Developmental Servic
descriptionFull:
This amendment directs the Department of Education to work collaboratively with the
Department of Behavioral Health and Developmental Services and the Department of Medical
Assistance Services on a plan for creating a new program to deliver flexible mental health funds
to divisions.
Schools have relied on $123 million in pandemic relief funds to fund mental health services,
which will be expiring by January 2025. State funding will likely be necessary to mitigate the
loss of services or maintain current levels of service. There is not currently a state structure or
funding mechanism that could deliver reliable, flexible mental health funds to schools. The
relevant state agencies possess the expertise needed to determine the most effective way to
structure and fund a program that can address short-term loss of funding as well as realize long-
term success. This is a recommendation from the Behavioral Health Commission.

descriptionFull:

handling all incoming mail currently directed to local Departments of Social Services including
Medicaid benefit applications and renewal notices. This will allow all returned mail to be
processed in one centralized location and will expedite routing of applications to Cover Virginia
and localities for processing. This amendment assists localities with handling the volumes of
mail due to Medicaid redeterminations and new benefits applications by allowing for
streamlining and standardizing front-end income mail processes as well as standardizing
handling of other incoming mail types. The estimated annual costs comes from and estimated
annual volume of 90,000 to 105,000 pieces of mail. Funding is eligible for a 75 percent federal
Medicaid match rate for eligibility and enrollment activities.

descriptionShort:
This amendment recommends that of the amounts provided for salary increases for direct care
staff and food and environmental services staff,
descriptionFull:
This amendment recommends that of the amounts provided for salary increases for direct care
staff and food and environmental services staff, $6.2 million of that amount be used to provide
salary increases for psychologists, social workers, housekeeping, and food services staff at state
psychiatric hospitals that will bring these positions’ salaries within 10 percent of the median
salary paid to these positions by other health care employers in the region. This is a JLARC
recommendation.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $1.7 million each year from the general fund to support Centers for
Independent Living to provide independent living
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $1.7 million each year from the general fund to support Centers for
Independent Living to provide independent living services including skills training, advocacy,
information and referral, peer mentoring, and transition to people with significant disabilities.
Transition services includes youth services, services to people trying to transition from nursing
facilities and other institutions, and services to prevent institutionalization. Funding is needed to
meet increasing requests for these services and increased cost of doing business including rent,
fuel and transportation. This increase would provide $100,000 annually to each of the 17
Centers for Independent Living.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $920,000 from the general fund each year for clients assigned to
participate in the Bridge Behavioral Health program
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $920,000 from the general fund each year for clients assigned to
participate in the Bridge Behavioral Health program. The Bridge Program is an inpatient
residential treatment center that serves men 18 years of age and older suffering from behavioral
and mental health challenges. During the first phase of the program, individuals participate in
evidence-based group cognitive behavioral therapy and individualized counseling with a
licensed professional as well as workforce development training and financial management
courses. During the second phase, participants stay in transitional housing in Charlottesville
where they are placed in career employment opportunities. At the conclusion of the transitional
housing program, clients also receive assistance obtaining permanent residency to aid to their
successful reentry into society. The Bridge Program invests $46,000 per inmate that is court
ordered to participate in the program but does not currently receive any state funding for the
clients. The funding is for the reimbursement of behavioral and mental health treatment services
for 20 of the projected 40 to 45 program participants from the state at $46,000 per client for a
total appropriation of $920,000 each year of the biennium.
primaryRecipientName: the reimbursement of behavioral and mental health treatment services for 20 of the projected 40 to 45 program participants from the state at $46
recipientRawText: for the reimbursement of behavioral and mental health treatment services for 20 of the projected 40 to 45 program participants from the state at $46,000 per client for a total appropriation of $920,000 each year of the biennium

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $125,000 each year from the general fund to the Department of
Social Services to work with Early Impact VA, the Virg
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $125,000 each year from the general fund to the Department of
Social Services to work with Early Impact VA, the Virginia Department of Health, and other
state agencies to develop the Home Visiting Program in accordance with the Virginia Plan for
Home Visiting and maximize state administered home visiting funding to meet matching
requirements for federal programs, including TANF, FFPSS, Medicaid and other relevant
revenue sources and report back preliminary findings and recommendations to the Chairs of the
House Appropriations and Senate Finance and Appropriations Committees by December 1,
2024. In the first year, Early Impact Virginia will use funds to develop and facilitate the
working group to make final program and funding recommendations to both committees,
conduct a thorough analysis of federal funding opportunities and regulations, conduct a
thorough analysis of current Virginia funding administration, develop the plan for system
transformation to streamline fiscal administration and reporting to support new financing
structures, and update progress and make recommendations to advance the Virginia Plan for
Home Visiting. In the second year, the funds shall be used to support local communities to
successfully implement system transformation including fiscal and administrative change.
primaryRecipientName: the Department of Social Services to work with Early Impact VA
recipientRawText: to the Department of Social Services to work with Early Impact VA, the Virginia Department of Health, and other state agencies to develop the Home Visiting Program in accordance with the Virginia Plan for Home Visiting and maximize state administered home visiting funding to meet matching requirements for federal programs, including TANF, FFPSS, Medicaid and other relevant revenue sources and report back preliminary findings and recommendations to the Chairs of the House Appropriations and Senate Finance and Appropriations Committees by December 1, 2024

descriptionFull:

population in each sheriff's office with primary law enforcement responsibilities, in accordance
with § 15.2-1609.1, Code of Virginia. Weldon Cooper Center for Public Service data is used to
project population growth.

descriptionFull:

for a five percent increase for all sheriffs and their Compensation Board-funded employees to
improve recruitment and retention. Currently, the base salary for an entry-level deputy sheriff is
$44,982 and there are more than 1,300 vacancies among Compensation Board-funded deputy
positions statewide.

provide a 9.3 percent salary increase for communications supervisor and communications
operator positions funded through the Compensation Board. These positions provide dispatch
services in sheriffs' offices. This amount is sufficient to cover the 64 communications
supervisors and 344 communications operators currently funded by the Compensation Board.
The current turnover for communications operator positions is 35 percent.

Opioid Use Reduction and Jail-Based Substance Use Disorder Treatment and Transition Fund
administered by the Department of Criminal Justice Services, to be used for a similar purpose.

descriptionFull:

million each year from nongeneral funds to the Virginia Health Workforce Development
Authority for operational costs to support health workforce initiatives across the
Commonwealth. Funding will match federal funding received from the United States
Department of Health Resources and Services Administration for the management of the
Virginia Area Health Education Centers. $250,000 each year will go toward oversight and
management of the graduate medical education programs for primary care and $250,000 each
year will provide central oversight and regulatory review of the Health Innovation Fund.

descriptionFull:

ready to begin a training program. Another $250,000 matching competitive grants the first year

models the first year and four organizations to support regional employer-led collective models
the second year based on GoVirginia nine regions with funding awards being matched by

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $75,000 from the general fund each year to support the Postpartum
Support Virginia's Warmline. This Warmline provides one-on-one support via phone, text,
email, social media, virtual, and in-person social support groups and peer mentors who spend an
extended amount of time with those struggling with postpartum anxiety. The Warmline is
staffed by staff or volunteers who have lived experience or professional experience with
perinatal mood and anxiety disorders.

generic medications to low-income, uninsured Virginians. The funding will support existing
programs to expand utilization during the biennium based upon the growth and success of the
existing programs, the loss of access to key brand medications, and the increasing cost of
generic medication.

descriptionFull:

maintenance, and other non-medical services. The Village model allows older adults to age in

connections to affordable services.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $250,000 each year from the general fund to support the
development and implementation of a statewide driver's licensing program to support foster care
youth in obtaining a driver's license. Funding will be made available to local departments to
reimburse foster care providers for increases to their existing motor vehicle insurance premiums
that occur because a foster care youth in their care has been added to their insurance policy. The
program may also reimburse foster care providers for additional coverage that provides liability
protection should a foster care youth get into or cause a catastrophic accident. Additionally,
funding shall be made available to foster care youth in Virginia's Fostering Futures Program to
assist in covering the cost of obtaining motor vehicle insurance. The department shall develop
reimbursement policies for foster care providers and foster care youth. The department shall
coordinate and administer the driver's licensing program based on best practices from similar
programs in other states, to include developing educational or training materials that educate
foster parents, private providers, and foster youth about: (i

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $6.0 million GF the second year to support existing Children's
Advocacy Centers in providing necessary mental health follow-up services, serving all of
Virginia’s children, and providing services to human trafficking victims. This amendment
supports Senate Bill 12, which establishes a statutory definition for children's advocacy centers,
provides that the centers may conduct interviews as part of human trafficking assessment, and
allows another child forensic interviewer to conduct a child interview during the course of child
abuse investigation if a children's advocacy center is not able to complete an interview within
14 days.

Assembly in 2022, grants were provided to community-based organizations partnering with
school divisions to create 14 additional before-school, after-school and summer learning
programs for school-age children attending high-poverty, low-performing schools.

This amendment provides $1,050,000 each year from the general fund for environmental

descriptionFull:

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $9,048,000 each year from the general fund to provide permanent
funding to support the VCU Pauley Heart Center. This
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $9,048,000 each year from the general fund to provide permanent
funding to support the VCU Pauley Heart Center. This funding will support programs and
expansion to maximize the center's impact for statewide workforce development and reduction
of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. This initiative will optimize workforce development,
expand critical cardiovascular disease research, prevent unnecessary emergency room visits,
build a more informed patient population, and lower state Medicaid expenditures.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $124.2 million GF the first year and $74.1 million GF the second
year, representing the first biennial installment o
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $124.2 million GF the first year and $74.1 million GF the second
year, representing the first biennial installment of the VCCS’s plan to address regional
workforce needs for in-demand jobs in high-demand industry sectors. Funding will prepare,
upskill, and reskill Virginians and expand upward mobility opportunities, providing Virginia’s
industries with the workers they need. The 23 community colleges are closely collaborating
along GO Virginia regional lines to better address economic development and workforce needs.
This request reflects an intentional, strategic alignment between business and industry in each
region. The convergence will allow for accelerated training and credentialing while placing
more students directly into open jobs with family-sustaining wages. The requested investment
will produce nearly 20,000 more credentialed workers for the workforce talent pipeline in high-
demand sectors aligned with 9 GO Virginia regions. The funding request is already supported
by $21.7 million in industry investment and will be matched with a $24.6 million future
industry investment and $10.6 million of redirected existing college resources.

investigations to monitor and address impacts of long COVID and provide grants to
organizations that serve populations disproportionately impacted by COVID-19, long COVID,
or related conditions. This amendment is based on a similar program in Minnesota.

recipientRawText: to the Department of Health to establish a program to conduct community assessments and epidemiologic investigations to monitor and address impacts of long COVID and provide grants to organizations that serve populations disproportionately impacted by COVID-19, long COVID, or related conditions

descriptionShort: This amendment directs the Department of Medical Assistance Services (DMAS
descriptionFull: This amendment directs the Department of Medical Assistance Services (DMAS

descriptionShort:
This amendment adds language directing the agency to implement a change in scope process
July 1, 2024 by which FQHCs may request a reimburse
descriptionFull:
This amendment adds language directing the agency to implement a change in scope process
July 1, 2024 by which FQHCs may request a reimbursement change to reflect the scope for
services that have been added or changed. It further provides that FQHCs can request this scope
of services change dating back to October 1, 2018 as long as the request is made no later than
October 1, 2024. Thereafter, a request for a change in scope must be made within 15 months of
the change taking place. Finally, this amendment authorizes DMAS to reimburse an FQHC for
unreimbursed costs for up to two years prior to the FQHC’s initial request for a change in scope.
This will allow the FQHCs to cover their costs of patient care during this period through receipt
of the full federal match for these reimbursements.

descriptionShort:

regulations to remove service limits for medical nutrition
descriptionFull:

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $100,000 in the first year from the general fund to the Department of
Medical Assistance Services to develop a compr
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $100,000 in the first year from the general fund to the Department of
Medical Assistance Services to develop a comprehensive plan for eating disorder treatment
services and submit the plan to the House Appropriations and Senate Finance and
Appropriations Committees and the Joint Commission on Health Care by July 1, 2025. This
amendment addresses the facts that Virginia Medicaid does not cover eating disorder residential
treatment for adults over the age of 21; current Medicaid reimbursement rates for intensive
outpatient, residential, and other covered services are not specialized to consider the specific
components needed for evidence-based eating disorder treatment; none of the eating disorder
providers in Virginia that offer intensive outpatient, partial hospitalization, or residential
services for eating disorder treatment accept Medicaid. Other states have set specialized
Medicaid reimbursement rate standards specifically for eating disorder treatment. This is a
recommendation of the Joint Commission on Health Care.

descriptionShort:
This amendment directs the Department for Medical Assistance Services to amend its
regulations to remove prior authorization for eating diso
descriptionFull:
This amendment directs the Department for Medical Assistance Services to amend its
regulations to remove prior authorization for eating disorder treatment. This amendment is
based on other states that have removed prior authorization for all levels of care for eating
disorder treatment to include inpatient, residential, partial hospitalization, and intensive
outpatient services. Vermont, the most recent state to do so, no longer requires concurrent
review of clinical documentation for admission to eating disorder treatment for any level of
care. This is a recommendation of the Joint Commission on Health Care.

descriptionFull:

injury providers report high attrition and difficulty filling open positions because of non-
competitive salaries and benefits. Delivery of programs and services suffer and client needs can
go unmet. This funding will support currently existing state contracted brain injury service
providers.

senior military institutions and to meet their growing needs with the aim to operate the Virginia

million each year as a placeholder. The actual revenue impact is to be determined.

descriptionFull:

of Senate Bill 328, which allows local governments to provide enhanced retirement benefits for
hazardous duty service to full-time salaried 911 dispatchers. The bill provides that such
enhanced retirement benefits apply only to service earned as a full-time salaried 911 dispatcher
on or after July 1, 2025, but allows an employer to provide such enhanced retirement benefits
for service earned as a full-time salaried 911 dispatcher before July 1, 2025, in addition to
service earned on or after that date. The bill has a delayed effective date of July 1, 2025.

of Military Affairs, they are the only fire department in the Commonwealth operated by state
employees. This makes the fire department unique as other departments in the Commonwealth
are local employees, federal employees, or contract employees. Firefighters in the
Commonwealth receive some form of Hazardous Duty Retirement.

descriptionFull:

assistant in each classroom for each day of the week for any school with performance below one
or more accreditation standards considered to be “Accredited with Conditions” under the state
accreditation system. JLARC notes that the state includes funding for less than 3,000
instructional assistants, while school divisions employ approximately 21,000. This amount is
higher than estimates provided in a prior year due to the large increase in the number of schools
accredited with conditions. This is an estimate. The actual fiscal impact is to be determined.

descriptionFull:

to increase the TAG award from $5,000 each year to $5,500 the first year and $6,000 the second
year for undergraduate and for qualified graduate and medical students. It also removes
language that states that payments to undergraduate students shall be greater than payments to
graduate and medical students based on a differential established by the State Council of Higher
Education for Virginia. The request to increase the TAG award are because amounts have
increased at the same rate as general fund spending for public higher education and now lags
behind the negative impacts of an inflationary economy.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides an additional $18.0 million each year from the general fund to begin
to address the long-standing in-state undergrad
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides an additional $18.0 million each year from the general fund to begin
to address the long-standing in-state undergraduate state appropriation disparity for George
Mason University. While Mason has received incremental increases in state support over the
past decade, they have been at a lower rate than most other Virginia doctoral institutions. When
state and tuition funding are combined, Mason is nearly $4,000 per in-state undergraduate
student FTE below the other Virginia doctoral institutions’ median allocation.
primaryRecipientName: George Mason University
recipientRawText: for George Mason University

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $124.2 million GF the first year and $74.1 million Gf the second
year, representing the first biennial installment o
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $124.2 million GF the first year and $74.1 million Gf the second
year, representing the first biennial installment of the VCCS’s plan to address regional
workforce needs for in-demand jobs in high-demand industry sectors. Funding will prepare,
upskill, and reskill Virginians and expand upward mobility opportunities, providing Virginia’s
industries with the workers they need. The 23 community colleges are closely collaborating
along GO Virginia regional lines to better address economic development and workforce needs.
This request reflects an intentional, strategic alignment between business and industry in each
region. The convergence will allow for accelerated training and credentialing while placing
more students directly into open jobs with family-sustaining wages. The requested investment
will produce nearly 20,000 more credentialed workers for the workforce talent pipeline in high-
demand sectors aligned with 9 GO Virginia regions. The funding request is already supported
by $21.7 million in industry investment and will be matched with a $24.6 million future
industry investment and $10.6 million of redirected existing college resources.

descriptionFull:

of electronic filing for Virginia's Bank Franchise Tax through a secure electronic portal
maintained by the Department of Taxation (authorized in the 2023 legislative session

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment reduces the Health Care Fund by $6.0 million each year and increases the
general fund provided to Medicaid by $6.0 million ea
descriptionFull:
This amendment reduces the Health Care Fund by $6.0 million each year and increases the
general fund provided to Medicaid by $6.0 million each year to reflect changes proposed in a
companion amendment to impose a 20 percent tobacco products tax on cigars or 30 cents per
cigar, whichever is less. Cigars are currently taxed at 20 percent of the manufacturer's sale price.
During the 2023 Session, the Department of Taxation revenue impact stated it is unknown to
what extent that the portion limiting the tax to $0.30 per cigar would reduce revenues. As a
placeholder, this assigns a revenue reduction of $6.0 million each year to the Health Care Fund
and backfills Medicaid with general fund for the impact.

descriptionFull:

service facilitation training and visits to reflect recommendations contained in the most recent
report on rebasing of Medicaid developmental disability Medicaid waiver services. While most
of the rates were updated as of July 1, 2022, rates for service facilitation did not get updated. A
service facilitator is a Medicaid-enrolled provider who is responsible for supporting the
individual enrolled in Medicaid waivers and the family/caregiver by ensuring the development
and monitoring of the Consumer-Directed Services Individual Service Plan, providing
employee management training, and completing ongoing review activities as required by the
Department of Medical Assistance Services for consumer-directed companion, personal
assistance, and respite services.

Conservation District education and outreach programs. Strong local conservation districts are
necessary as Virginia intensifies its efforts to reduce nonpoint sources of pollution throughout
the Commonwealth and to meet the goals of the Chesapeake Bay Total Maximum Daily Load
commitment.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $500,000 GF the first year for UVA Health to update its imaging
equipment in its mobile mammography van, currently located in the City of Manassas, VA.
Specifically, funding is requested to purchase the Hologic 3Dimensions Mammography System
in order to offer 3D mammograms to women participating in the mobile mammography van's
outreach services. With the updated imaging equipment, UVA Health anticipates expanding its
community outreach mammography events in partnership with organizations, local employers,
churches, local government, and public health agencies located in Prince William, Culpeper,
and Fauquier Counties and in the cities of Manassas and Manassas Park and towns of
Haymarket and Culpeper.

influenza, based on guidelines developed by the Department of Agriculture and Consumer
Services in consultation with affected industries.

This amendment provides $140,000 each year from nongeneral funds for the potential impact

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $140,000 each year from nongeneral funds for the potential impact
of Senate Bill 472, which allows local governments to provide enhanced retirement benefits for
hazardous duty service to full-time salaried 911 dispatchers. The bill provides that such
enhanced retirement benefits apply only to service earned as a full-time salaried 911 dispatcher
on or after July 1, 2025, but allows an employer to provide such enhanced retirement benefits
for service earned as a full-time salaried 911 dispatcher before July 1, 2025, in addition to
service earned on or after that date. The bill has a delayed effective date of July 1, 2025.

descriptionFull:

of the use of any opioid settlement funds. Such review is to ensure compliance with guidelines,
procedures, and criteria set forth by the Opioid Abatement Authority, and in turn, compliance
with specific national agreements and Virginia court orders related to such settlements, the
overarching statewide memorandum of understanding for allocation of opioid abatement
monies, and the provisions of Article 12, Chapter 22 of the Code of Virginia. The language
requires such reviews effective with the current fiscal year.

This amendment provides funding for the impact of Senate Bill 333, which directs the Board of

descriptionFull:

Medical Assistance Services to amend the state plan for medical assistance services to include a
provision for payment of medical assistance for coverage of fertility preservation for individuals
diagnosed with cancer who need treatment for that cancer that may cause a substantial risk of
sterility or iatrogenic infertility, including surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy. The bill also
establishes that it is a Class 3 felony for a health care provider to provide assisted conception
treatment to a patient and use the health care provider's own gamete without the written consent
of the patient.

provision for payment of medical assistance for coverage of fertility preservation for individuals
diagnosed with cancer who need treatment for that cancer that may cause a substantial risk of
sterility or iatrogenic infertility, as defined in the bill, including surgery, radiation, or
chemotherapy. The bill also requires health insurance policies, subscription contracts, and
health care plans to provide such coverage for such individuals.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $688,120 the first year and $198,000 the second year from the
general fund for workforce development funding at SVHE
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $688,120 the first year and $198,000 the second year from the
general fund for workforce development funding at SVHEC. Of these amounts $198,000 each
year is for one full-time BSN/MSN level nursing instructor to meet significant local needs and
$490,120 in the first year is provided to replace outdated equipment in the center’s welding lab
that has reached its end of life and a robotic simulator needed to modernize training programs.
Welding is a critical occupation in Southern Virginia and employers are struggling to fill
vacant, high-paying jobs in this field.

descriptionFull:

working conditions. Funds are provided if additional consultants are needed to support the

This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the associated costs of

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the associated costs of
legislation that requires every employer to enroll in the E-Verify program by January 1, 2025,
and to use the program for each newly hired employee who is to perform work within the
Commonwealth. The bill also requires the Attorney General to request the U.S. Department of
Homeland Security, once each calendar quarter, to provide a list of agencies and employers that
are enrolled and participate in the E-Verify program and shall make such list available on the
Attorney General's website.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 GF each year as a placeholder to support implementation of
Senate Bill 295, which restricts any foreign adversary or foreign business from acquiring any
interest in land in the Commonwealth and requires registration with the Secretary of the
Commonwealth. The bill requires the Secretary to report annually by December 1 on the
registrations and any penalties assessed for failure to register and to submit such report to the
Governor and the General Assembly.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the potential impact of

descriptionFull:

pending legislation that would prohibit public bodies from awarding contracts to acquire an
electric vehicle or electric vehicle component from a business unless such business provides a
sworn declaration from the manufacturer certifying that every person involved in the production
of such components and every person involved in the sourcing, manufacturing, or mining of the
material used in such electric vehicle or electric vehicle component did not use forced labor or
oppressive child labor.

legislation to be introduced in the 2024 session
descriptionFull:

legislation to be introduced in the 2024 session to prohibit hedge funds from buying single-
family homes. The forthcoming bill prohibits hedge funds from ownership of single-family
homes without imposing a tax, and establishes definitions and special rules regarding the
applicable taxpayers, single-family residences, and disqualifications. This bill also establishes
reporting requirements and penalties for non-compliance.

Sessions as recommended by the Crime Commission. The one-time cost of $228,600 is to
process the 25,400 records that would qualify for automatic sealing pursuant to the provisions
of the bill. The department incurs a one-time cost of $9 per automated expungement.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $250,000,000 each year from nongeneral funds to be deposited into
the Virginia College Opportunity Fund established
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $250,000,000 each year from nongeneral funds to be deposited into
the Virginia College Opportunity Fund established pursuant to Senate Bill 501, which directs
the board of the Virginia College Savings Plan to deposit $250 million per year of surplus
moneys from the Plan's fund into the Virginia College Opportunity Fund. The bill provides that
such deposit shall not be made or shall be reduced in any year in which the College Opportunity
Investment Advisory Committee determines that certain conditions relating to the Plan's funded
status are not met. The bill provides that financial management of the Fund is the responsibility
of the board of the Plan but authorizes the board of the Virginia College Opportunity
Endowment to manage a scholarship program funded by the Fund. The bill establishes an
individual and corporate income tax subtraction for donations to the Fund. Under the bill, the
Endowment provides scholarships to students who attend or plan to attend one of 12 eligible
universities named in the bill. The bill provides that only such students who meet the eligibility
requirements for a Federal Pell Grant and commit to being employed in Virginia, or being
enrolled in postgraduate education in Virginia, for at least eight years after graduation from an
eligible university are eligible for such scholarships.
primaryRecipientName: the Fund
recipientRawText: to the Fund

program until sufficient earnings accrue out of the Fund to provide for salaries and fringe
benefits.

Special Reserve Fund, pursuant to § 30-19.1:4, Code of Virginia, to address the projected
corrections bedspace fiscal impact of Senate Bill 44, which establishes penalties for the owner
of a firearm who allows a minor to possess the firearm, if the minor subsequently uses the
firearm to commit a crime or cause bodily injury or the minor posseses the firearm in a school
zone.
primaryRecipientName: the required deposit to the Corrections Special Reserve Fund

descriptionShort:
This amendment reduces revenue by a $50,000 GF each year as a placeholder for Senate Bill
523 related to sales tax entitlements from public
descriptionFull:
This amendment reduces revenue by a $50,000 GF each year as a placeholder for Senate Bill
523 related to sales tax entitlements from public facilities. This bill could decrease the amount
of general fund revenues available for appropriation. Due to uncertainty regarding the projects
that would benefit from this expansion of the public facility entitlement, the magnitude of this
potential decrease is unknown.

descriptionShort:
This amendment reduces general fund revenue by $2.0 million each year as a placeholder for
the revenue impact to exempt certain baby product
descriptionFull:
This amendment reduces general fund revenue by $2.0 million each year as a placeholder for
the revenue impact to exempt certain baby products from sales and use tax pursuant to Senate
Bill 511. The actual revenue impact is to be determined.

descriptionShort:
This amendment accompanies Senate Bill 556, a bill increasing the maximum amount of the
historic rehabilitation tax credit that may be claim
descriptionFull:
This amendment accompanies Senate Bill 556, a bill increasing the maximum amount of the
historic rehabilitation tax credit that may be claimed by a taxpayer in any taxable year from $5.0
million to $10.0 million, beginning in taxable year 2024. This amendment assumes a general
fund revenue reduction of $15.0 million each year. The actual revenue impact is to be
determined.

descriptionShort:
This amendment accompanies Senate Bill 555, a bill establishing an income tax credit for
individuals who sell residential real property that
descriptionFull:
This amendment accompanies Senate Bill 555, a bill establishing an income tax credit for
individuals who sell residential real property that is the taxpayer's primary residence and is
located in the Commonwealth to a first-time homebuyer, as defined by the bill. This amendment
assumes a general fund revenue reduction of $30.0 million each year as a placeholder. The
actual revenue impact is to be determined.

descriptionShort:
This amendment accompanies Senate Bill 512 establishing an income tax credit in taxable
years 2024 through 2028 for eligible expenses incurr
descriptionFull:
This amendment accompanies Senate Bill 512 establishing an income tax credit in taxable
years 2024 through 2028 for eligible expenses incurred in converting office buildings to
residential uses. The bill proposes an aggregate credit cap of $30.0 million, and this amendment
assumes full utilization of the credit, which reduces general fund revenue by $30.0 million each
year. The actual revenue impact is to be determined.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund as a placeholder for any
impact pursuant to Senate Bill 519, which eliminate
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund as a placeholder for any
impact pursuant to Senate Bill 519, which eliminates the one-year waiting period for a divorce
to be decreed on the grounds of cruelty, reasonable apprehension of bodily hurt, or willful
desertion or abandonment.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $175,000 GF each year as a placeholder for the potential fiscal
impact of Senate Bill 514, which reduces the period
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $175,000 GF each year as a placeholder for the potential fiscal
impact of Senate Bill 514, which reduces the period of limitations for the collection of court
fines and costs. The goal of this amendment is to provide general fund dollars to offset any
estimated reduction in NGF collections due to Senate Bill 514.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $100,000 GF each year as a placeholder for any potential fiscal
impact of Senate Bill 654, which relates to the time
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $100,000 GF each year as a placeholder for any potential fiscal
impact of Senate Bill 654, which relates to the timeline for collecting criminal court fines and
fees.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 GF each year as a placeholder amount for the potential
fiscal impact of pending legislation related to sente
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 GF each year as a placeholder amount for the potential
fiscal impact of pending legislation related to sentence modifications for prior marijuana-related
convictions.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $100,000 GF each year for the Compensation Board to distribute to
the City of Norfolk Sheriff's Office and the Arlin
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $100,000 GF each year for the Compensation Board to distribute to
the City of Norfolk Sheriff's Office and the Arlington County Sheriff's Office to partner with
Birth in Color RVA in implementing a doula job training pilot program. The program would
give job training to incarcerated persons at the Norfolk City Jail and Arlington County
Detention Facility.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the fiscal impact of
Senate Bill 526, which amends the Resale Disclosure
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the fiscal impact of
Senate Bill 526, which amends the Resale Disclosure Act.

Norfolk to match funding raised by the Urban Leagu
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $10.0 million from the general fund the first year to the City of
Norfolk to match funding raised by the Urban League of Hampton Roads to revitalize The
Village shopping center.

descriptionFull:

highest behavioral and social-emotional learning support needs in Superintendents Region 2.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides provides $17.9 million GF the first year and $18.2 million GF the
second year to support the state share of one coll
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides provides $17.9 million GF the first year and $18.2 million GF the
second year to support the state share of one college and career specialist per high school as
proposed by SB 518. This is an estimate. The actual fiscal impact is to be determined.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $3,750,000 the second year from the general fund to support a
shovel-ready Corps of Engineers project to clean up on
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $3,750,000 the second year from the general fund to support a
shovel-ready Corps of Engineers project to clean up one of the most contaminated sites in the
Chesapeake, at Money Point in Chesapeake VA. $11.25 million has been appropriated in the
federal budget and $3.75 million state funding is needed to complete the cleanup at this site.
The project is a community priority which will help to improve the health of the Elizabeth River
while also stimulating economic development around Money Point. Language specifies that any
remaining shall be carried over to the next fiscal year.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $5.0 million GF each year to provide Norfolk State University staff
and employees with a livable wage.
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $5.0 million GF each year to provide Norfolk State University staff
and employees with a livable wage.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides language to allow the University to have the autonomy to provide
unfunded scholarships to merit students without con
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides language to allow the University to have the autonomy to provide
unfunded scholarships to merit students without consideration of need. Doing so allows the
University another tool with which to attract, enroll, and retain the most qualified students
regardless of their financial condition.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $4.0 million in each year from the general fund to maintain Norfolk
State University’s Spartan Innovation Academy, i
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $4.0 million in each year from the general fund to maintain Norfolk
State University’s Spartan Innovation Academy, including faculty and student devices, IT
support, and continued development to enhance the learning experience.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $800,000 in each year from the general fund to support child care
centers on community college campuses. Of the amou
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $800,000 in each year from the general fund to support child care
centers on community college campuses. Of the amounts provided, $600,000 is designated for
Tidewater Community College Norfolk campus to build and operate a free child care center for
their students.
primaryRecipientName: Tidewater Community College Norfolk campus to build and operate a free child care center for their students
recipientRawText: for Tidewater Community College Norfolk campus to build and operate a free child care center for their students

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $825,000 each year from the general fund to support the
establishment of the Stillbirth Support Grant Program pursua
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $825,000 each year from the general fund to support the
establishment of the Stillbirth Support Grant Program pursuant to pending legation. The
program will provide up to $1,500 in support to families experiencing stillbirth for qualifying
expenses. Families will apply within a year of the stillbirth. The fund will cover expenses such
as un-covered medical bills related to stillbirth and burial or disposal expenses for the remains.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the associated impact of
Senate Bill 513, which defines "transportation
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the associated impact of
Senate Bill 513, which defines "transportation protection agreement" as an agreement that
provides for the coordination and arranging of all professional services related to transportation
of human remains or cremated remains beyond the distance stated in the preneed funeral
contract. The bill clarifies that transportation protection agreements are not considered preneed
funeral contracts.

agencyName: Health and Human Resources FY24-25 FY25-26
descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the potential impart of
Senate Bill 521, which defines "declinable prene
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the potential impart of
Senate Bill 521, which defines "declinable preneed funeral guarantee fee" as an optional and
declinable fee agreed to by a preneed funeral contract purchaser, if offered by a seller, for which
the cost of the supplies and services as described in the preneed funeral contract are guaranteed.
The bill describes certain requirements that must be met for funeral service licensees to offer
declinable preneed funeral guarantee fees. The bill directs the Board of Funeral Directors and
Embalmers to adopt emergency regulations to implement the provisions of the bill.

of Truth Community Development Corporation to provide additional funding each year to assist

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $250,000 GF each year to the department to make available
competitive grants for Chesapeake Bay watershed environmental education opportunities for
students. This amendment would increase the available funds from $250,000 to $500,000 in
each year of the biennium.

descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 GF each year as a placeholder amount for the potential
fiscal impact of Senate Bill 524, which permits a locality, by ordinance, to allow the installation

must require that installation be completed in compliance with certain National Fire Protection
Association standards, requirements, and specifications.

This amendment provides $50,000 GF each year as a placeholder for the fiscal impact of
Senate Bill 516 which authorizes a local government t
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 GF each year as a placeholder for the fiscal impact of
Senate Bill 516 which authorizes a local government to provide by ordinance for lawful seizure
of all terrain vehicles operated on a highway or sidewalk within the locality.

descriptionShort:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the potential impact
from Senate Bill 520, which provides that, for the
descriptionFull:
This amendment provides $50,000 each year from the general fund for the potential impact
from Senate Bill 520, which provides that, for the purposes of the Virginia Workers'
Compensation Act, "occupational disease" includes injuries or diseases from conditions
resulting from repetitive and sustained physical stressors, including repetitive and sustained
motions, exertions, posture stresses, contact stresses, vibrations, or noises. The bill provides that
such injuries or diseases are covered under the Act and that such coverage does not require that
such repetitive or sustained physical stress occurred over a particular time period, provided that
the time period over which such physical stress occurred can be reasonably identified.
